Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:

History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ with coronary artery disease status post 
coronary artery bypass graft, chronic systolic congestive hearth 
failure, chronic kidney disease (baseline Cr ___, hypertension, 
hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus on insulin, and new 
pulmonary nodules and pleural thickening consistent with 
malignancy, recently discharged from ___ one day prior to 
re-admission following hospitalization for acute-on-chronic 
congestive heart failure and acute-on-chronic kidney disease, 
now re-presenting with new chest pain and changed dyspnea.
.
Last night as he was going to sleep he had sudden-onset 
left-sided chest pain, ___, which felt like pressure, radiating 
down left side, and felt similar to his pain with previous 
myocardial infarction. The pain was also associated with "gaspy" 
dyspnea which is different in character from the dyspnea he was 
recently admitted with in the setting of his acute-on-chronic 
congestive heart failure. He had some nausea, no vomiting, no 
sweating, no jaw radiation, no pleurisy, no alleviation of 
dyspnea with change in position. He took Dilaudid 2x with no 
relief. He also noted increased leg swelling and thinks his L 
leg is more swollen than the R. He had no leg pain, and no 
personal or family history of deep vein thrombosis.
.
He denied chills, fevers, coughing, sputum production. 
.
Vitals in the ED were 97.9 81 128/58 18 99%. Initial labs showed 
WBC of 28.6 with 96% PMNs, HCO3 of 21, and Cr of 3.8. BNP 18872. 
First set of troponins was negative. EKG showed Vpaced rhythm 
and was negative for MI per Sgarbossa criteria. CXR showed 
slightly worsened right lower lobe opacification which might 
represent worsening atelectasis or pneumonia, only mild vascular 
congestion, unchanged from ___, and no edema. He was 
treated presumptively for health care associated pneumonia given 
his increased dyspnea and increased opacification on xray and 
his worsened leukocytosis. IV antibiotics were started, cultures 
were drawn. No CTA was done due to his high Cr. He was admitted 
to Medicine for evaluation of possible pneumonia.
.
On the floor his VS were 96.7 108/57 72 18 96% 2L NC. The 
patient was having only mild chest pain and reported that it was 
much improved with morphine given in the ED. He was not dyspneic 
and had no other complaints.
.
ROS: He denied HA, new abdominal pain, diarrhea, frank blood in 
stool, new joint pain, dysuria, and new skin changes.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient is a ___ with multiple comorbidities who was 
discharged from ___ yesterday following admission for 
acute-on-chronic congestive heart failure and acute-on-chronic 
kidney disease, now re-presenting with new chest pain and 
changed dyspnea concerning for health care associated pneumonia.
.
ACTIVE ISSUES:
.
# Dyspnea: The patient had multiple risk factors for acute 
coronary syndrome (known coronary artery disease, previous 
myocardial infarction, hypertension, diabetes), multiple risk 
factors for pulmonary embolism (status post recent 
hospitalization, possible hypercoagulable state secondary to 
probably malignancy), and was at risk for health care associated 
pneumonia (given his recent hospitalization). The most likely 
etiology for his new dyspnea and chest pain was health care 
associated pneumonia, as he had an acutely worsened 
leukocytosis, a new neutrophilia, and highly suggestive findings 
on x-ray, and a recent hospital stay. However, he had had no 
fevers, no chills, no cough, and no sputum production. Also on 
the differential was acute coronary syndrome (given his risk 
factors and his description of the pain, though unlikely given 
clear findings of pneumonia on chest xray and a negative first 
set of troponins. EKG was less helpful in the setting of paced 
rhythm). Pulmonary embolism was also a possibility given that he 
had a recent hospitalization during which he was less mobile 
than at baseline and given his probable malignancy. His 
description of sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea and history 
of left leg swelling was also concerning for pulmonary embolism. 
However, he was not hypoxemic or tachycardic and since the chest 
x-ray was so suggestive of pneumonia there was another 
explanation for his symptoms.  Treatment was begun with 
levofloxacin.  Legionella urine antigen was sent and was 
negative. The patient's dyspnea did not recur during 
hospitalization and he was sent home on levofloxacin for total 
8-day course.  The patient will follow up with his primary care 
provider upon discharge.
.
# Chest pain: Given the patient's description of acute onset 
chest pain with squeezing pressure, sweating, and radiation to 
the left arm, another set of cardiac biomarkers was sent to rule 
out myocardial infarction. No changes suggestive of ischemia 
were seen on initial EKG, however in the setting of the 
patient's paced rhythm the EKG was difficult to interpret.  On 
Day 2 of hospitalization, the second set of biomarkers showed a 
troponin level of 0.47, consistent with non-ST elevation 
myocardial infarction. The patient's chest pain had resolved so 
no morphine was given; he was already on his home beta blocker.  
He was started on daily aspirin.  He was not put on a heparin 
drip due to his history of massive retroperitoneal bleed from a 
ruptured renal cyst.  Serial cardiac enzymes were sent and 
showed a peak troponin level of 0.66 and CK-MB level of 38, both 
of which were trending down at the time of discharge.  The 
patient had no further recurrence of his chest pain during the 
course of his hospitalization and he was sent home on a regimen 
of daily aspirin.
.
# Acute hematocrit drop: On Day 2 of admission, the patient's 
Hct was 30.4, down from 35 the day prior.  He had no symptoms of 
bleeding and vital signs remained within normal limits.  He was 
typed and screened and consented for a blood transfusion.  
Repeat labs showed a stable hematocrit and no transfusion was 
necessary. He was discharged home with a plan to maintain his 
current weekly Hct checks which he gets for his epoeitin 
treatments.  
.
INACTIVE ISSUES:
. 
#. Lung nodules/pleural thickening: Based on CT scan read, 
nodules are most likely malignant, and the patient has 40 pack 
year smoking history and previous asbestos exposure. Nodules are 
unlikely to be contributing to respiratory issues but may be 
contributing to appetitie loss and weight loss.  Outpatient 
pleural biopsy is planned for ___.
 
#. Chronic systolic congestive heart failure: Given the 
patient's recent hospitalization for acute-on-chronic CHF in the 
setting of acute-on-chronic renal failure, and his remaining 
mild crackles and edema on initial exam, he was monitored 
closely for need for more diuresis and furosemide was titrated 
accordingly with good response.  He was discharged home on his 
usual home dose of furosemide.
.
# Chronic renal failure: The patient was maintained on a 
low-potassium, low-phosphate, fluid-restricted diet and diuresis 
with furosemide was titrated based on daily fluid balance.
.  
# Abdominal pain: The patient has noted several weeks of 
intermittent right lower quadrant/flank/inguinal pain. Concern 
for acute intraabdominal process was low given benign abdominal 
exam and recent negative abdominal CT scan. The differential 
includes muscle strain or muscle spasm (pain seems to improve 
with movement so stiffness may be contributing to his 
discomfort, though range of motion is full and does not 
exacerbate pain) or neuropathic pain (pain is described as raw 
and burning, intermittent with duration of minutes, and 
alleviated by changes in position which is consistent with an 
intermittent nerve entrapment etiology). The patient's pain 
remained well controlled on hydromophone as needed during his 
hospitalization, but he may benefit from treatment for 
neuropathic pain on an outpatient basis.
.
#. Diabetes: The patient's home glargine was continued with an 
insulin sliding scale.  
.  
#. Hyperlipidemia: The patient's home statin was continued.    
.  
#. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's home metoprolol and 
amiodarone were continued. THe patient was off coumadin and 
aspirin since his renal hemorrhage.  Given his likely non-ST 
elevation myocaridal infarction just prior to this admission, it 
was decided in consultation with his primary care provider to 
place him back on daily aspirin at a dose of 162mg per day.  
.  
# Hypertension: The patient's home metoprolol/isosorbide were 
continued with holding parameters for low BP.  The patient's ___ 
was discontinued on previous admission in the setting of 
hyperkalemia to 5.9. The patient remained normotensive 
throughout his hospitalization.  
.  
# Hypothyroid: The patinet's home levothyroxine was continued.  
.  
# Gout: The patient's home allopurinol was continued.

summary: You were admitted for further evaluation and treatment of your shortness of breath and chest pain. You had a chest x-ray which showed a possible infection in your lungs (a pneumonia), and you were started on antibiotics to treat this. You also had some blood tests done which suggested that your chest pain may have been caused by a small heart attack. In discussion with your primary care provider, we decided to treat this heart attack with conservative measures, so we gave you aspirin, monitored your EKGs, and monitored your blood tests.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY
===================
___ is a ___ woman with hepatitis 
C-induced liver cirrhosis complicated by recurrent 
hepatocellular carcinoma (liver resection ___ per patient but 
___ per records, transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) in 
___, repeat TACE ___ who presents with confusion, likely 
due to acute kidney injury and possibly hepatic encephalopathy. 

ACUTE ISSUES: 
=============== 
#Confusion 
Likely dehydration/acute kidney injury as the etiology of her 
confusion. Hepatic encephalopathy also on the differential. She 
had significant asterixis on initial exam. Has not had previous 
episodes of HE. Infectious workup, including blood cultures and 
urine culture, was nonsigificant at the time of discharge. She 
received fluid and albumin for her ___ (see below) and was 
treated with lactulose and rifaximin. Her hepatic encephalopathy 
improved drastically, and she returned to baseline by the time 
of discharge, with no asterixis on exam. She was A&Ox3 at 
discharge. 

#Acute kidney injury
Baseline Cr appears to be 0.9. It was elevated to 2.1 on 
admission and downtrended with albumin and fluids. Pt states a 
history of chronic poor oral which may have worsened over the 
several days prior to presentation. She takes torsemide and 
spironolactone at home, which was stopped on this admission. Her 
Cr at discharge was 1.5. The patient was educated on the 
importance of keeping good hydration at home, and she expressed 
understanding. The patient will be followed up closely as an

summary: You became very confused at home. For your confusion, we gave you lactulose (which increases how often you stool) and rifaximin (an antibiotic). Your confusion went away with these medications. You were found to have acute injury to your kidneys because you were dehydrated. You received fluid and albumin through your IV. Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment/Plan:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with metastatic lung CA, 
recurrent malignant pericardial effusion, recurrent DVT and PE 
s/p IVC, SVC and brachiocephalic filter placement who presented 
with cough and dyspnea for 1 week and was found to have CTA 
concerning for PE and pericardial effusion with tamponade 
physiology. She was taken semi-urgently to the catheterization 
laboratory for pericardiocentesis with balloon pericardiotomy 
and subseqnetly required surgical creation of 2 pericardial 
windows with internal drainage. 
. 
# Malignant Pericardial Effusion:  She presented with her third 
occurence of malignant pericardial effusion with evidence of 
tamonade physiology that required drainage and balloon 
pericardiotomy. 240ml of sanguineous fluid was drained from 
pericardial sac and she tolerated the procedure well. A 
pericardial drain was left in overnight but removed the next 
afternoon when it had drained very little overnight. However, 
later that day she again was noted to have an increased pulsus 
up to 32mmHg with doppler with recurrence of tamonade physiology 
with new RV collapse on bedside ECHO. Overnight she was urgently 
taken to CT surgery for pericardial window with internal 
drainage. In that surgery window was created draining into the L 
pleural space and a L chest tube was placed that initially 
drained 400cc of serosanguinous fluid. Due to technical 
difficulties with window placement and concern that the window 
might not be effective, a pericardial incision was also made 
just righ of midline and 200cc of bloody fluid was drained from 
the pericardium and a pericardial drain was placed in that 
incision. Pt was intubated for the proceedure and kept intubated 
overnight as a precaution, but was extubated without incident 
the next day. After 24hrs the L chest tube was removed as it had 
decreasing drainage but the pericardial drain was left in place 
due to very high output (1L over first 24hrs and 500cc/day each 
of the following 2 days). Pt also received 1 unit PRBC on ___ 
as her Hct had drifted down to 22.4. There was concern that the 
window might not function when the pericardial drain was removed 
and the pt might go back into tamponade. As a result, the 
pericardial tube was clamped on ___ and the patient was 
monitored overnight without significant change in vital signs or 
symptoms. On ___ interventional pulmonology placed a pleurx 
catheter in the L pleural space and roughly 350cc was drained 
from the pleurx. On ___, the pericardial drain was removed 
after ECHO confirmed that there was constrictive physiology but 
no hemodynamically significant effusion 36hrs after the tube had 
been clamped. Although the initial plan was to drain every other 
day, the pleurx was also drained on the ___ due to significant 
weeping on the dressing where the pericardial drain had been in 
place. An additional 200cc of fluid was drained at that time 
with process stopped as pt started to experience pain.  On the 
floor, another 150mL of fluid was drained from pleurx which 
again was terminated due to pain. Prior to discharge, she was 
drained one last time.  She was given morphine po for these 
drainages.  She was discharged with follow-up at IP and with ___ 
services as well as prescription for morhine for continued 
drainages.  Pulsus remained stable at between 10 and 14mmHg for 
remainder of hospital stay.  Oxygen saturation remained low ___ 
on room air and decreased to 88-89% with ambulation.  She was 
discharged with home oxygen.  She was scheduled for outpatient 
cardiology follow-up with outpatient echocardiogram for 
monitoring.  
.
# Pulmonary embolism: She was first diagnosed with a pulmonary 
embolism in ___ along with BUE clots. She received SVC and 
IVC filters and has been on chronic lovenox. She was found to 
have an anti-factor Xa level of >2.0 consistent with therapeutic 
levels. CTA on this admission identified a subsegmental PE in an 
artery to the left lower lobe. Because of the reaccumulation of 
her pericadial effusion with solid pericardial mass component, 
it was determined that the heparin drip should not be resumed 
immedicately. From time of initial pericardial window, heparin 
gtt or other therapeutic anticoagulation was held until pt 
transfered back to OMED service on ___.  Upon transfer to 
floor, she was started back on heparin gtt and then transitioned 
to lovenox upon discharge.  
.
# R anterior/apical pneumothorax: on ___, daily PCXR noted 
small apical R pneumothorax. This was confirmed by CXR Pa/Lat 
which also noted small anterior component to R apical 
pneumothorax. This finding was monitored with daily PCXR and 
found to be stable over the next 6 days. Cause of this PTX most 
likely related to significant R pleural effusion/atelectasis due 
to underlying lung malignancy more than any of the operative 
proceedures that were done as none of them in theory should have 
involved the R lung pleura. However, with intubation and line 
placement, iatrogenic PTX is on the differential.  
.
# Infectious Disease: No cultures were positive during CCU stay. 
Around time pt went to OR for pericardial window, she had 
developed a temperature of 100 and was slightly more 
tachycardic. There was some concern for possible 
post-obstructive PNA in setting of known lung mass so initially 
started on vanco/cefepime for this on ___ and also knowing that 
pt would be going to OR and receiving operative instrumentation. 
Abx were stopped Am ___ after 48hrs when it became apparent 
that there was no significant infectious process as the cause of 
pts symptoms.
.  
# Metastatic lung adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma of the lung was 
discovered in ___, metastatic to right temporal lobe and now 
s/p stereotactic radiotherapy.  S/P cisplatin and navelbine last 
Tx ___. Pt was kept on prednisone at oncology request due to 
her brain mets. Neuro attending recommended that keppra be 
stopped. Upon transfer to oncology floor, she was started on 
chemotherapy with taxotere which she tolerated well.  She also 
had 3 days of increased steroids (dexamethasone 8mg bid x 3 
days) at the time of chemotherapy and also received neupogen to 
increase her counts after chemo.
.
# S/P Cyberknife for brain metastasis: She was finishing a 
decadron taper on admission.  She received increased doses at 
8mg bid x 3 days around the time of chemotherapy and was 
discharged back on dexamethasone 2mg daily until she meets with 
her neuro-oncologist for the swelling around her neck secondary 
to SVC syndrome.  She also had Horner's syndrome with right eye 
ptosis and anhidrosis. She will need an outpatient MRI head and 
C-spine for further evaluation of her horner syndrome.
.
# Access: Pt had known right upper extremity DVTs on admission 
with swelling around right arm for which she had been on 
lovenox.  She received a right PICC at the ICU for access.  
Later, on the floor, RUQ ultrasound revealed right IJ and right 
cephalic DVTs.  Left UE US had small non-occlusive residual clot 
is seen in the lower IJ. Discussion was held with surgery and IV 
nurse regarding ___ this right PICC given persistent DVTs.  
However, pt had very poor access and it was not guaranteed that 
access could be obtained in left arm given clot in left IJ as 
well.  Thus, it was decided to continue to use right PICC while 
pt was in house with close monitoring of right arm 
circumference.  Right arm swelling remained stable.  Right PICC 
was ___ upon discharge.  She was scheduled for outpatient MRV 
to evaluate for access for future chemo sessions and will likely 
need chest port.

next
2 hours waiting for someone to check on her and help her. Her
daughter, who lives with her, came in the room at 6am and found
her on the ground. She got her husband to help pick the patient
up and they cleaned her up and put her back to bed. At that
point, she could stand on her own but felt "shaky." 

Later in the morning, she tried to get up again to use the
bathroom but she was unable to make it due to weakness and
urinated on herself again. Her daughter cleaned her up again and
then helped her to the couch. She noticed that she was slumped 
to
the left and then called EMS. On EMS arrival, the daughter
noticed a left facial droop as well. 

Notably, on ___, patient reports an episode of vertigo and
word finding difficulty as well as difficulty writing with her
right hand, lasting 30 minutes. 

She has felt generally weak recently and has had about 7 falls 
in
the last 3 weeks, including one on ___ for which she sustained 
a
wrist fracture. She had this surgically repaired yesterday. She
has been off her home Aspirin in preparation for the surgery for
the past week. 

Lastly, she does report a history of stroke "back in the ___
causing left sided weakness, though she is not sure what caused
it. 

On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred
vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, lightheadedness,
vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties 
comprehending speech.  Denies focal numbness, parasthesiae. No
bowel incontinence or retention.

Ms. ___ is a ___ old woman with a history of HTN, IDDM, 
remote stroke, whom presented with left sided weakness and 
coordination deficits concerning for lacunar stroke with 
ataxic-hemiparesis. Her MRI was negative for acute stroke and we 
currently believe that she experienced recrudescence of her old 
stroke symptoms in the setting of hyperglycemia and poorly 
controlled diabetes. Patient's left sided weakness improved as 
her glucose because
more appropriately managed. Imaging did show an old infarct that 
appears to involve the R pre and post central gyri, which would 
go along with her symptoms. She was assessed by physical 
therapy, whom after working with her for several sessions felt 
it was safe for her to go home.

History of Present Illness:

in ___ with supraclavicular lymph node lesion that had been

worsening pain. Pt presents from clinic for expedited workup and 
symptom management of pain and nausea/vomiting. 

In ___, CT scan showed 5.9 x 5.6 x 4.6 cm mass centered at the 
right clavicular head with muscular and bone erosion as well as 
a obliteration of the right internal jugular vein and encasement 
of the right common carotid artery. ENT was consulted, and the 
patient underwent laryngoscopy which showed immobility of the 
right vocal cord, potentially related to her tumor. Oncology was 
consulted, and recommended a biopsy and CT Torso for further 
evaluation. A CT torso revealed a right breast nodule (likely 
old) and thyroid nodules. She underwent a thyroid ultrasound, 
which showed an echogenic somewhat spongiform appearing nodule 
in the right isthmus measuring 1.8 x 1.3 
cm and a heterogeneous, hypoechoic vascular nodule in the lower 
pole of the left thyroid measuring 2.5 x 2.3 x 2.8 cm with areas 
of 
punctate increased echogenicity (biopsy deferred to outpatient 
setting). An ___ biopsy of her mass was performed and 
revealed moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of 
unknown primary with cells with signet ring morphology and 
immunohistochemistry positive for CK7 (diffuse), CK20 (patchy), 
and TTF-1 (rare cells). Pathology felt that the overall 
morphology in immunophenotype were nonspecific as to the site of 
origin, but they favored an upper GI or pancreaticobiliary 
primary, although spread from long thyroid salivary gland, 
breast or gynecologic primary would be less likely, but remain 
in the differential diagnosis. She was noted to have a mass in 
the right breast on exam and as an outpatient, she had 
diagnostic imaging performed ___. Directed right breast 
US showed a circumscribed hypoechoic mass measuring 1.7 x 1.7 x 
0.5 cm with internal vascularity and no dominant posterior 
features at 12 o'clock 2 cm from the nipple. Mammogram was 
considered BI-RADS 4B and ultrasound-guided core biopsy of the 
dominant mass at 12 o'clock in the right breast was recommended, 
although breast imaging felt that it was unlikely to be the 
primary. On ___, she had a PET scan, which showed a 5.6 
cm FDG avid right supraclavicular mass as well as asymmetric FDG 
uptake in the left arytenoid possibly secondary to activity 
within the arytenoid itself or underlying ill-defined node. She 
also had an FDG avid right paratracheal lymph node and a 
heterogeneous thyroid gland with low-level activity noted in the 
left lobe for which ultrasound was recommended. The right breast 
lesion did not show any FDG avidity.

Since discharge, she has had some progressive dyspnea on 
exertion, which she thinks is related to deconditioning, 
especially if she is climbing the stairs. She has also noticed 
increasing hoarseness of her voice over approximately the past 
week, although she thinks food is going down okay.  She has had 
significant pain at the mass itself as well as in the right 
shoulder and upper back. She has been trying to control this 
with oxycodone 10 mg, which she uses about twice daily. However, 
pain control has been inadequate and she has suffered from 
nausea and vomiting secondary to opiates. For this, she has been 
taking Zofran twice a day, and this has not been controlling her
symptoms. She has not been able to tolerate a lot of PO, but 
weight is stable from last admission on ___. She continues 
to have a chronic cough, which is mostly dry. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  Denies fevers, chills, sweats, diarrhea, 
black stools, leg swelling or redness.  She does have an area of 
numbness in the C5 distribution on her right forearm as well as 
pain in the entire right arm at times, which is relieved by 
putting the arm in a dependent position.  No symptoms of 
lightheadedness and no pain in the right side of her face or 
facial flushing. 

 
Past Medical History:
Pt admitted on ___ with bleeding right supraclavicular

immobility of the right vocal cord, potentially related to her 
tumor. Oncology was consulted, and recommended a biopsy and CT 
Torso for further evaluation. CT C/A/P ___ revealed a right 
breast nodule (likely old) and thyroid nodules. She underwent a 
thyroid ultrasound, which showed an echogenic somewhat 
spongiform appearing nodule in the right isthmus measuring 1.8 x 
1.3 cm and a heterogeneous, hypoechoic vascular nodule in the 
lower pole of the left thyroid measuring 2.5 x 2.3 x 2.8 cm with 
areas of punctate increased echogenicity (biopsy deferred to 
outpatient setting).

Soft Tissue Core Biopsy ___:
Adenocarcinoma, moderately to poorly differentiated.
Note: The biopsy shows numerous tumor cells with cribriform, 
nested, and glandular architecture infiltrating fibrous tissue. 
Scattered mucinous tumor cells with signet-ring morphology are 
present. By immunohistochemistry, tumor cells show the following 
immunophenotype:
- Positive: CK7 (diffuse), CK20 (patchy), TTF-1 (rare cells).
- Negative: CDX-2, Napsin A, thyroglobulin, GCDFP-15, 
mammaglobin, estrogen receptor,
progesterone receptor.
- Equivocal: PAX-8 (weak and patchy nuclear staining).
The overall morphology and immunophenotype are not specific as 
to the site of origin. An upper gastrointestinal or 
pancreaticobiliary primary is favored; spread from a lung, 
thyroid, salivary gland, breast, or gynecologic primary is less 
likely but remain in the differential diagnosis.

She was noted to have a mass in the right breast on exam and as 
an outpatient, she had diagnostic imaging performed ___. 
Directed right breast US showed a circumscribed hypoechoic mass 
measuring 1.7 x 1.7 x 0.5 cm with internal vascularity and no 
dominant posterior features at 12 o'clock 2 cm from the nipple.

biopsy of the dominant mass at 12 o'clock in the right breast 
was recommended, although breast imaging felt that it was 
unlikely to be the primary. On ___, she had a PET scan,

well as asymmetric FDG uptake in the left arytenoid possibly 
secondary to activity within the arytenoid itself or underlying 
ill-defined node. She also had an FDG avid right paratracheal

activity noted in the left lobe for which ultrasound was

IMAGING:
EGD/EUS ___:
Normal EGD. Normal radial EUS of the stomach with no evidence to

with
no evidence of a pancreas or biliary malignancy. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old woman with carcinoma of unknown 
primary. Admitted in ___ with supraclavicular lesion that had 
been growing for at least three months and is now causing 
erosion and worsening pain. Patient presented from clinic for 
expedited workup and symptom management of pain and 
nausea/vomiting. 

# Adenocarcinoma of Unknown Primary:
Only known site is R supraclavicular lesion. Biopsy with 
adenocarcinoma, signet ring cells raising concern for GI 
primary. EGD and EUS without evidence of malignancy. PET scan 
with increased uptake in L thyroid, R supraclavicular lesion, R 
paratracheal lymph node, left ileum. Patient also has R breast 
lesion without increased FDG uptake but without known primary 
and on ipsilateral side concerning for possible malignancy. Of 
note, biopsy of supraclavicular mass negative for ER, PR, and 
HER2 (HER2 equivocal in biopsy staining but negative by FISH), 
so if breast malignancy were primary, would be triple negative. 
Pt unable to lie flat for breast biopsy while inpatient and 
could not be rescheduled for while the pt would still be 
in-house. Outpatient providers can consider ordering outpatient 
US-guided breast core biopsy. While in-house, pt underwent FNA 
of left thyroid nodule, the results of which were pending on 
discharge. 

# Right Supraclavicular Lesion:
Biopsy consistent with adenocarcinoma, unknown primary as above. 
Immunohistochemistry positive for CK7 (diffuse), CK20 (patchy), 
TTF-1 (rare cells), CD117 (weak and patchy), p63 (rare), and 
CK5/6 (rare). Pathology felt that the overall morphology in 
immunophenotype were nonspecific as to the site of origin, but 
they favored an upper GI or pancreaticobiliary primary, which 
was r/o with unremarkable EGD/EUS. Given its size (5.6cm) and no 
obvious other primary source, it is most likely that the 
supraclavicular mass is the primary cancer, most likely of a 
skin adnexal derivation. On admission, mass was causing patient 
significant right supraclavicular fossa pain and right 
shoulder/upper back pain i/s/o large (approximately 6cm) mass in 
the R supraclavicular fossa with extensive encasement 
of/impingement on surrounding vascular and anatomic structures 
and with erosion through the skin. Pain likely due to brachial 
plexus nerve involvement, given C5/C6 numbness and weakness on 
exam and neuropathic pain in arm (pins and needles).  Pain was 
controlled per pain consult recs with oxycontin 10mg q6am and 
q2pm, oxycontin 20mg q10pm, oxycodone 10mg q4h PRN, 
acetaminophen 650mg q6h, Tramadol 50mg q6h PRN, gabapentin 900mg 
TID, IV dilaudid 0.25-0.5mg q3h PRN for breakthrough pain. The 
ulcerated supraclavicular fossa lesion was managed per wound 
care consult recommendations. Five fractions of palliative 
radiation therapy were performed, session 1 ___ and 
completed on ___. 

# Nausea/vomiting:
On admission, pt reported recent nausea/vomiting at home that 
started after she began taking oxycodone for pain. Pt tolerating 
regular diet and weight stable from last admission on ___ 
(130 lbs). Albumin 4.2 on admission. No nausea/vomiting while 
in-house except i/s/o motion sickness from being wheeled back 
from radiation. Motion sickness managed with Dramamine PRN prior 
to transport for procedures. Nausea/vomiting controlled with PRN 
IV Zofran, PO Compazine, and PO Ativan while in-house, and pt 
discharged with PO Zofran, Compazine, and Ativan PRN. 

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
[] F/u pending thyroid nodule FNA results
[] Continue to titrate pain medications as needed for optimal 
pain control
[] Consider R breast mass biopsy if thyroid FNA results 
unremarkable

# Diarrhea: The patient had some episodes of diarrhea on 
admission. He was found to be C diff negative and his diarrhea 
resolved.

# Multiple Myeloma: The patient has a history of multiple 
myeloma for which has declined further treatment per family 
meeting during the patient's last hospital admission. The 
patient was continued on his home acyclovir, allopurinol, 
multivitamin. The patient's calcitonin nasal spray was held, per 
previous report from outpatient provider. The patient's calcium 
remained within normal limits during admission. He was started 
on furosemide as above. The patient should f/u with his 
outpatient oncologist for further management. 

# CAD: The patient was restarted on his home lovastatin on 
discharge. The patient should f/u with outpatient providers to 
consider discontinuing this medication given goals of care. 

# Hypertriglyceridemia: The patient's fenofibrate was held at 
discharge due to concern regarding the risk of rhabdomyolysis in 
the setting of concurrent statin use and worsening kidney 
disease. 

# Acute on chronic kidney disease: The patient had Cr of 3.0 
elevated from previously baseline 2.5-2.8 after IV diuresis. The 
patient was evaluated with urine lytes which showed FENa 9.0% in 
the setting of IV furosemide therapy. Cr trended down to 2.8 
upon discharge. The patient was continued on his home sodium 
bicarbonate. 

# Anxiety, depression: continued home escitalopram, pt will 
restart home lorazepam at discharge. 
# Hypertension: continued home metoprolol 
# Neuropathic pain: continued home gabapentin 
# BPH: continued home tamsulosin 
# GI: continued ranitidine, omeprazole, simethicone

intermittent hypercalcemia

- continue to monitor COPD, consider uptitration of advair as

History of Present Illness:
___ with h/o bipolar disorder, CKD, neurogenic bladder, HTN who 
presents with several months of skin lesions. Patient reports 
that approximately 3 months ago, he first noticed a multiple 
isolated lesions on his legs, arms, and trunk that he thought 
were bedbug bites.  These were pruritic and became even more 
itchy when scratched.  He denies exposure to sick contacts, 
outdoors, new detergents.  He went to his dermatologist who took 
a biopsy and diagnosed with him contact dermatitis.  He was 
referred to an allergist, but was unable to be tesed ___ active 
rash.  His dermatologist prescribed steroids which helped the 
pruritus but caused him to break out into boils.  His steroids 
were discontinued, and he was instructed to soak in the bath, 
and use warm towel compresses to try to express the fluids from 
the boils.  He says that he was able to express very little 
purulent material.  He went to his dermatologist again on ___, 
who swabbed the lesions for culture, and prescribed 
dicloxacillin.  Patient did not improve on this over the next 
few days, and reported chills and a fever of 102.6F (tympanic) 
today.  The final culture for the swab returned today, growing 
MRSA, and the patient was contacted by his dermatologist who, in 
the context of high fever, referred him to the ED for further 
evaluation and management.

On arrival to the ED, initial vitals were: 99 126 142/64 18 95% 
RA. Labs notable for WBC 16.6 w/ L shift and Cr 1.7 (baseline). 
Blood and urine Cx drawn and given Vanc 1g IV x1. VS at 
transfer: 98.4 100 126/75 18 95% RA.
  
Currently, patient is comfortable.  Reports mild pruritus of the 
lesions, but otherwise denies chills, lightheadedness, 
dizziness, chest pain, joint pain.

ROS is positive for new cough, SOB, dysuria with increased 
urinary frequency (patient has been self-catheterizing for ___ 
years for neurogenic bladder--negative uro workup), hard stools 
in the setting of discontinuing laxatives for ~week.

CXR ___:

Questionable infectious process in the lungs.  Given the 
patient's history, followup of the patient in four weeks after 
completion of antibiotic therapy is required.  If finding is 
persistent, assessment with chest CT might be considered to 
exclude other potential etiologies for the lung abnormalities.
 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ with BPD, CKD, neurogenic bladder, HTN, and recent allergic 
dermatitis presenting with fever and worsening skin lesions 
despite antibiotics.
 
# Skin lesions/fever: Patient with history of chronically dry 
skin presenting with multiple MRSA+ abscesses over bialteral 
legs, arms, and back.  Patient was afebrile during course of 
hospitalization and blood and urine cultures were not positive 
for 
infection.  Patient came in to the BI on dicloxacillin, which 
had been prescribed by his dermatologist.  Dicloxacillin was 
discontinued and patient was given IV vancomycin x48 hours with 
great improvement of skin lesions.  For his pruritus, patient 
was given sarna lotion and diphenhydramine with moderate effect. 
 His dermatologist was contacted and recommended bleach baths 
3x/week and mupirocin. Dermatology scheduled follow-up visit 
with patient. Patient received an HIV test ___ concern for 
immunocompromise in the setting of diffuse involvement.  One day 
prior to discharge, patient was transitioned to PO doxycycline 
(versus Bactrim, given CKD).  Patient tolerated this well, and 
was discharged on a 14 day course of doxycycline. 
  
# Dysuria: Patient has a ___ year history of neurogenic 
bladder which has been worked up extensively in the past, per 
the patient.  Also documented history of BPH.  Patient has been 
self-cathing for the past ___ years and reports occasional 
UTIs.  On admission, patient reported recent dysuria and 
increased frequency.  As patient had a CC of fever, UA and UCx 
were obtained.  Both were negative.  Patient continued to 
self-cath during hospitalization without event/complaint.

# cough, SOB: Patient has extensive smoking history and may have 
mild COPD or other lung disease. CXR was obtained and was 
questionable for infectious process in the lungs; however, 
patient improved subjectively without intervention.  No oxygen 
requirement during hospitalization.  However, given 
abnormalities on CXR, it was recommended that patient have 
repeat CXR in 4 weeks.

# CKD: On admission, patient's creatinine elevated to 1.8.  He 
was slightly tachycardic with increased BUN (although this 
appeared to be the patient's baseline).  Possibly volume down in 
setting of decreased PO and increased urinary frequency.  
BUN/creat > 20.  Patient given 1L NS for possible prerenal 
etiology.  Creatinine trended down to 1.5.  One day prior to 
discharge, patient again with creatinine of 1.8 and was again 
given 1L NS.  Given patient's CKD, he was written for 
doxycycline versus bactrim for continued treatment of his MRSA 
skin infection.  Medications, otherwise, were all renally dosed.

# Bipolar disorder: Continued home meds.

# Hemorrhoids: Continued home bowel regimen in addition to 
senna, colace.  

# HTN: Continued home meds.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
# abnormal CXR:  Radiology suggested that patient, given h/o 
smoking and COPD, should receive repeat CXR in 4 weeks.  If CXR 
findings persistent, assessment with CT recommended.

# Continued bactroban and bleach baths given extent of MRSA 
infection

summary: You were admitted to the ___ for skin infection. You required intravenous antibiotics for several days during your hospitalization. After we saw that your skin was getting better, we switched you to oral antibiotics. You should continue taking these oral antibiotics after discharge. It is very important you finish the entire course of your antibiotics, even if you feel you do not need them anymore.
